question: If the probabilities of two items in a distribution are \( p(i) = 0.4 \) and \( p(j) = 0.6 \), calculate the entropy \( H \) of the combined distribution \( p(i) + p(j) \).
solution:
The combined probability is:

\[
p(i) + p(j) = 0.4 + 0.6 = 1
\]

The entropy \( H \) of a distribution is given by:

\[
H = -\sum p(k) \log p(k)
\]

For the combined distribution, since \( p(i) + p(j) = 1 \), we can calculate the entropy as follows:

\[
H = -[p(i) \log p(i) + p(j) \log p(j)]
\]

Calculating each term:

\[
H = -[0.4 \log(0.4) + 0.6 \log(0.6)]
\]

Using natural logarithms:

\[
H \approx -[0.4 \times (-0.9163) + 0.6 \times (-0.5108)] \approx 0.4 \times 0.9163 + 0.6 \times 0.5108 \approx 0.3665 + 0.3065 = 0.673
\]

Thus, the entropy of the combined distribution is approximately:

\[
\boxed{0.673}
\]
